title: 111_hr1803
content:
The "Veterans Business Center Act of 2009" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It establishes the Veterans Business Center Program. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a Veterans Business Center Program to provide entrepreneurial training and counseling to veterans. A Director will oversee the program and report to the Associate Administrator for Veterans Business Development. The Director will also designate veterans business centers through a regulatory process. The Director will establish a process to designate entities as veterans business centers and publicly announce the designation and grant awards. Initial grants of $200,000 will be provided to each veterans business center annually for up to 5 years, with the possibility of growth funding grants after the initial period. The Director can grant $150,000 annually for up to 3 years to veterans business centers for entrepreneurial development, counseling, and procurement assistance. Centers must meet performance benchmarks after 3 years to continue receiving funding. The Director can grant $150,000 annually for up to 3 years to veterans business centers for entrepreneurial development, counseling, and procurement assistance. Centers must provide a 50% non-Federal match for the funds received, with the option for a waiver based on hardship. Priority is given to applications from veterans business centers serving communities with specific economic criteria. The Director can grant funds for establishing veterans business centers in underserved areas with high veteran populations, particularly from Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom. Additionally, an annual training program is developed for center staff to enhance their knowledge and skills in operating the centers effectively. The Director will develop a training program for veterans business centers in consultation with various organizations. Upon enactment, existing centers will be designated as veterans business centers and eligible for grants. The Director will prioritize applications for grants to establish veterans business centers in rural areas if a report shows insufficient access for veterans. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. The Director of the Veterans Business Center program is authorized to make grants totaling $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2010 and $14,000,000 for fiscal year 2011. These grants are for developing specialized programs to assist veteran-owned small businesses in securing capital and repairing damaged credit, as well as providing informational seminars on securing loans for veteran-owned small businesses. The Veterans Business Center program offers grants to assist veteran-owned small businesses in securing loans, improving financial presentations, accessing financing sources, and providing counseling to owners who are members of the reserve components of the armed forces. The Veterans Business Center program offers grants to assist veteran-owned small businesses in preparing for deployment during contingency operations and helping unemployed veterans become entrepreneurs. The Director may award a center up to $75,000 in grants, with $1,500,000 authorized for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Additionally, a procurement assistance grant program will be established. The Director can provide grants to veteran-owned small businesses through the grant program to assist in identifying suitable contracts, preparing for subcontractor and prime contractor roles, and offering training and business advisement, especially in construction trades. The Director can provide grants to veteran-owned small businesses for technical assistance in Federal procurement processes, compliance with regulations, and bonding requirements. The maximum grant award is $75,000, with an authorization of $1,500,000 for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Additionally, a grant program for service-disabled veteran-owned small businesses will be established by the Director. The Director can award grants up to $75,000 to veterans business centers for outreach programs, training in various business aspects, and assistance in securing business opportunities for service-disabled veterans. The Veterans Business Center program can receive grants of over $75,000 annually, with an authorization of $1.5 million for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. The program also hosts a Veterans Entrepreneurial Development Summit every two years to provide networking, education, and support to veteran-owned businesses and service organizations. The Director authorizes $450,000 for outreach to veterans in high unemployment areas. Surviving spouses are included in the definition of 'veteran' and 'veteran-owned small business'. The term 'veteran' includes members of the reserve components of the armed forces as specified in section 10101 of title 10, United States Code. The term 'veteran-owned small business' also includes small businesses owned by members of the reserve components. SEC. 3. The Administrator must report biannually to Congress on the appointments and activities of the interagency task force.

SEC. 4. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of the Act on small businesses owned by veterans and provide recommendations on how to better serve them. Passed the House of Representatives on July 28, 2009. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
